summary_reasoning: The report demonstrates high originality through multiple quantified, company-specific syntheses and original theses. A standout insight is the detailed peer comparison of iPhone dollar content, specifically estimating Broadcom's content at $20 versus $12 for Skyworks and $5 for Qorvo, which provides a unique competitive angle not found in public filings. The analyst also presents a specific, testable thesis regarding Broadcom's 70% capture of a $60B-$90B AI accelerator Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM) by 2027, based on a specific count of five current and two new customers. Furthermore, the report synthesizes the VMware acquisition with a specific margin trajectory, projecting non-GAAP operating margins rising to the mid-60% range by 2029. Finally, the analysis of the Apple relationship provides a clear catalyst (2025 displacement of Wi-Fi/Bluetooth) while offering a technical justification for the defensibility of FBAR filters (expertise in non-silicon materials like aluminum nitride). These insights offer explicit causal links and quantified implications that are highly decision-relevant and go well beyond boilerplate sector commentary.

insights_classified.text: Broadcom’s average dollar content sold into the iPhone close to $20... well above our estimates for peers like Skyworks ($12) and Qorvo ($5.)
Management reiterated a $60 billion-$90 billion serviceable addressable market for its three first customers in 2027, of which we expect it to capture roughly 70% share.
We project non-GAAP operating margins rising to the mid-60% range in fiscal 2029, from 60% in fiscal 2024 [due to VMware integration].
FBAR filters are built on non-silicon materials like aluminum nitride... expertise for non-silicon materials is harder to find and develop [preventing Apple displacement].
AI revenue is now more than a fourth of total revenue and roughly half of chip revenue.
